The Martians might have different chemical bases in their DNA, or run off RNA alone. Maybe their amino acids will be mirror images of ours.
But its origin and evolution would be entirely different.
It might accomplish many of the same tasks and be recognisable as members of the same category (computers; living things)
such as amoebas or bacteria or even something like those teddy-bear tardigrades.
Finally we’d have something to compare ourselves to, and who’s to say we won’t decide the other way has some advantages?

The way Montana State’s Sara Waller sees it,
there is a middle ground between fanatical preservation and free-for-all exploitation.
We might still study how the resources of alien worlds could be used back home, but the driving force would be peer review rather than profit.
Martian life could appear superficially similar to Earth life, taking forms we might recognise, but its programming would be entirely different.
From a scientific perspective, passing up the opportunity to study a completely new biology would be irresponsible
Happily, we do have one example of a land grab made good here on Earth
